answers.text: that men and women are different in terms of sexual arousal patterns

qas.question: How is this reflected in the studies?

answers.text: in how their genitals react to sexual stimuli of both genders or even to non-human stimuli.

qas.question: What are some dimensions of sexual orientation?
What do mens sexual orientations tend be focused on?
What do researches believe must be taken into account for women in these studies?

context: These studies suggest <a0_0>that men and women are different in terms of sexual arousal patterns<a0_0/> and that this is also reflected <a1_0>in how their genitals react to sexual stimuli of both genders or even to non-human stimuli.<a1_0/> Sexual orientation has many dimensions (<a2_0>attractions, behavior, identity<a2_0/>), of which sexual arousal is the only product of sexual attractions which can be measured at present with some degree of physical precision. Thus, the fact that women are aroused by seeing non-human primates having sex does not mean that women's sexual orientation includes this type of sexual interest. Some researchers argue that women's sexual orientation depends less on their patterns of sexual arousal than men's and that other components of sexual orientation (like <a4_0>emotional attachment<a4_0/>) must be taken into account when describing women's sexual orientations. In contrast, men's sexual orientations tend to be primarily focused on the <a3_0>physical component of attractions<a3_0/> and, thus, their sexual feelings are more exclusively oriented according to sex.
